Stewart: 'Kurt is right'

div.p: Kurt Busch was suspended Monday for threatening Sporting News reporter Bob Pockrass. But Sprint Cup champion Tony Stewart finds no fault with what Busch did. | StockCartoons | K. Petty's take | Busch's suspension | SI: Busch at crossroads

div.p: Pocono has always been one of NASCAR's most challenging tracks. Now it has a new surface and 100 fewer miles. What can drivers and fans expect this weekend? | Testing adds to activity | Chase candidates | SI: Almirola's Chase chances

div.p: Halfway to the Chase, the contenders are coming into focus. Some are virtual locks to make the playoffs; others are safe bets. But some big names are in deep trouble. | JJ dominates Dover | Dover lessons | SI: Test ban may be loosened

div.p: NASCAR was dismissed as a party to the Drive 4 Diversity lawsuit brought by Michael Rodriguez.
As a result of his remarks at Dover, Kurt Busch won't be racing this weekend at Pocono Raceway. Was his suspension deserved?
Kurt Busch was suspended until June 13 by NASCAR following his comments made to Sporting News' Bob Pockrass. CineSport's Tara Petrolino discusses the incident with Pockrass.

Sporting News NASCAR reporter Bob Pockrass was the object of Kurt Busch's ire at Dover International Speedway. Pockrass shares his side of the story with Steven Levine and Tom van der Voort in this Sporting News/Rowdy video.

div.h4: Dover: Jimmie Johnson in championship form
div.p: Jimmie Johnson is dominant at Dover International Speedway. Jeff Gordon's bad luck continues. Carl Edwards falls out of the top ten.
Is Hendrick Motorsports NASCAR's best team after Jimmie Johnson's win at Dover? What caused a huge 13-car crash? CineSport's Brian Clark and Sporting News' Bob Pockrass discuss.

img.alt: Pocono 400 preview: New surface, shorter race offer big challenges

div.p: Pocono has always been one of NASCAR's most challenging tracks. Now it has a new surface and 100 fewer miles. What can drivers and fans expect this weekend?
